DL,

 

I have actually found that judicious use of underscores helps in this
case since many GUI runners display them as spaces.  Therefore, you can
write things like "UseCase_HighTide_TallShip_BridgeDown" or
"Negative_BlackBox_InvalidProductID" to organize your test cases and
make them easier to understand in a report.

 

Hope that helps,

 

Rocco

 

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
David Saff
Sent: Saturday, May 30, 2009 3:14 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Have a description of a test

 






DL,

You could create a Description annotation, which would be available to
test-run listeners. However, we do not actively maintain the
junitreport task (the hard-working folks at the apache ant project do
that), so you'd have to ask them to add such functionality to their
reporter.

That said, I usually try to make my test names as descriptive as
possible, so that there's not much information that's needed to be
added in a free-text description. It's not always
greatReadingCamelCase, and can feel a little ridiculous, but you only
have to type your method names once, so the cost is low.

David Saff

On Fri, May 29, 2009 at 9:54 AM, eldamidame <eldamidame@...
<mailto:eldamidame%40yahoo.fr> > wrote:
> Hi everybody !!
>
> Is there a way to put a description on a TestCase like
>
> @Test(description="improve speed tests")
>
> and after when a junitreport is generated have something like in the
html report :
>
> --------------------------------------------------------
> Class        |    description  | status | failure | type
> --------------------------------------------------------
>
> Thanks, DL
